title: 'Don't behave like this': Prince Harry rejects a reporter's questions in tense moment
text:
CLOSE Prince Harry and Duchess Meghan visit southern Africa to experience their culture and help those in need. USA TODAY

Prince Harry rebuffed a reporter's questions while in Malawi earlier this week.

Sky News' Rhiannon Mills approached the royal at the Mauwa Health Centre Tuesday, E! News and Entertainment Tonight report.

"That short conversation, what do you hope to achieve through it?" a voice on video can be heard asking the Duke of Sussex.

"What?" Harry responds, seemingly surprised. "Ask them."

"Is that why it's important for you to come here and talk to them?" the journalist presses.

"Rhiannon, don't behave like this," Harry says.

As to why Harry may have been so short with the royal correspondent, a person familiar with the situation but not authorized to speak publicly said royal correspondents are well aware the royal family does not partake in unscheduled interviews, nor do they give the media commentary while at royal outings.

After the exchange, Sky News passed along an apology to Harry, per the source.

Sky News declined to comment on the exchange. USA TODAY has reached out to the royal communications team.

Prince Harry compares 'malicious' media coverage of Duchess Meghan to late Princess Diana

Prince Harry & Meghan show off baby Archie on Day 3 of their Africa tour

Prince Harry in a discussion with young people during at the Mauwa Health Centre in Blantyre, Malawi, on Oct. 1, 2019. (Photo: DOMINIC LIPINSKI/POOL, EPA-EFE)

The same day, Harry struck out against the British media's "malicious" and "relentless" coverage of his wife, Duchess Meghan, in an emotional open letter.

"I have been a silent witness to her private suffering for too long. To stand back and do nothing would be contrary to everything we believe in," he wrote in a statement published Tuesday on their official website.

Prince Harry compared the media treatment of Duchess Meghan to that of his late mother, Princess Diana, who died in a car crash in Paris in 1997 while evading paparazzi.

"My deepest fear is history repeating itself," he wrote. "I’ve seen what happens when someone I love is commoditised to the point that they are no longer treated or seen as a real person. I lost my mother and now I watch my wife falling victim to the same powerful forces."

Following the publishing of a private letter, the royals are suing Associated Newspapers, which owns The Mail on Sunday for the misuse of private information, infringement of copyright and breach of the Data Protection Act 2018, according to the statement. Any damages rewarded "will be donated to an anti-bullying charity," they added.

The Mail on Sunday newspaper said in a statement to the Associated Press Tuesday night that it will defend itself "vigorously" against the lawsuit and “stands by the story” in question, which concerns publication of a letter Meghan had written to her estranged father.

“Specifically, we categorically deny that the duchess’s letter was edited in any way that changed its meaning,” the tabloid said in a statement.
